The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 may be cited as the Act. It includes higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002, also known as the Act, increases penalties for mail and wire fraud. Section 1341 and 1343 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to impose a maximum penalty of 20 years. Additionally, a new section 1348 is added to address securities fraud with fines and imprisonment up to 25 years for fraudulent schemes related to securities. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for mail and wire fraud, with fines and imprisonment up to 25 years for fraudulent schemes related to securities. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud and tampering with official proceedings, with fines and imprisonment up to 20 years. It also amends the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 enhances penalties for securities fraud and tampering with official proceedings, including fines and imprisonment up to 20 years. It also directs the United States Sentencing Commission to promptly review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, consider new guidelines or amendments for corporate officers committing fraud, and submit policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission is asked to update sentencing guidelines for securities, pension, and accounting fraud to reflect the seriousness of the offenses and ensure consistency with other directives. They should consider circumstances that may warrant exceptions and ensure adequate offense levels for obstruction of justice and fraud cases with a high number of victims. The Sentencing Commission is requested to update sentencing guidelines for fraud offenses with a high number of victims, make necessary changes to ensure consistency, and meet the purposes of sentencing. They are also urged to act promptly and issue the guidelines within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include claims for violation of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of securities as non-dischargeable debts. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes claims for violation of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of securities as non-dischargeable debts. Additionally, subparagraph (A) outlines the types of judgments, orders, settlement agreements, and payments owed by the debtor that are not dischargeable. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section, Sec. 1349, which requires corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The certification must state that the financial statements accurately represent the issuer's operations and financial condition. Violations of this section can result in criminal penalties of fines up to $5,000,000 and imprisonment up to 20 years. The new section, Sec. 1349, in Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, imposes penalties of up to $5,000,000 in fines or up to 20 years in prison, or both, for willful violations. SEC. 7. ATTEMPTS AND CONSPIRACIES TO COMMIT CRIMINAL OFFENSES.

    Any person who attempts or conspires to commit any offense against the United States shall be subject to the same penalties as those prescribed for the offense. 

SEC. 8. INCREASED CRIMINAL PENALTIES UNDER SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934.

    Penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 have been increased to $5,000,000 in fines or up to 20 years in prison, or both. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY FREEZE AUTHORITY FOR THE SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY FREEZE AUTHORITY FOR THE SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION. Amendment to Section 21C(c) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to petition for a temporary order to escrow extraordinary payments by an issuer during an investigation of possible securities laws violations. The Securities and Exchange Commission can request a temporary order to freeze extraordinary payments by an issuer during an investigation. The order must be entered after notice and a hearing, unless impracticable or against public interest. The temporary order is effective immediately, served to the parties involved, and remains enforceable for 45 days unless modified by a court. The Securities and Exchange Commission can request a temporary order to freeze payments during an investigation. The order can be extended for up to 90 days if violations are charged before its expiration. The Securities and Exchange Commission can request a temporary order to freeze payments during an investigation, subject to court approval. If no violations are charged before the expiration of the order, the escrow will terminate, and disputed payments will be returned. The Securities and Exchange Commission can freeze payments during an investigation with a temporary order, subject to court approval. If no violations are charged before the order expires, disputed payments with accrued interest will be returned to the issuer or affected person. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to Section 21C(c)(2) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 empower the Commission to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. This authority allows the Commission to issue orders prohibiting such individuals from holding these positions permanently or for a specified period. The Commission can issue an order to prohibit individuals who have violated regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. This can be permanent or for a specified period based on the person's conduct. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize retaliation against informants providing truthful information on Federal offenses to law enforcement. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 10 years.
